title: Resources for Multiple Myeloma
author: Alicia Barney

content: When you’re looking for more support to deal with multiple myeloma , there are many resources to help. You can learn more about treatment options and recent research from trustworthy nonprofit organizations and about people’s experiences through online communities. Personal blogs and support groups can offer emotional support and connect you with other people with the condition.
Websites and social media can be informative and useful, but don’t use them for medical advice. Take your concerns and questions to your doctor.
There is both good and bad information online. Be careful to choose sources you can trust. Ask yourself:
Here are some sources to get you started.
bullets: Who runs this site? Are they selling anything?
Is this information based on scientific research?
Is this site up to date?
Do these claims seem too good to be true?

Websites and social media can be informative and useful, but don’t use them for medical advice. Take your concerns and questions to your doctor.
There is both good and bad information online. Be careful to choose sources you can trust. Ask yourself:
associated_bullets: Who runs this site? Are they selling anything?
Is this information based on scientific research?
Is this site up to date?
Do these claims seem too good to be true?

content_blocks.text: Here are some sources to get you started.

sections.heading: Nonprofit Organizations
content: These groups provide reliable information about multiple myeloma . You can read the latest news and get facts from experts. They can also connect you with local support groups held in person and online.
bullets: Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation

content_blocks.text: These groups provide reliable information about multiple myeloma . You can read the latest news and get facts from experts. They can also connect you with local support groups held in person and online.

bullets: National Cancer Institute’s multiple myeloma information
Myeloma Crowd/HealthTree
American Cancer Society’s multiple myeloma page
International Myeloma Foundation

items: National Cancer Institute’s multiple myeloma information
American Cancer Society’s multiple myeloma page

sections.heading: Blogs
content: Many people with multiple myeloma write about their experiences online. These blogs often chronicle details about treatments as well as other personal asides unrelated to health. Remember, they aren’t written by experts and shouldn’t be used for medical advice.
This website lists many blogs written by people with myeloma and links to recent posts in one place: https://www.myelomablogs.org
bullets: Multiple Myeloma Mom
Julie’s Myeloma Moments, Musings and Living Life with a Bucket List
Debs’ Journey with Myeloma
Ian’s Myeloma Blog

content_blocks.text: Many people with multiple myeloma write about their experiences online. These blogs often chronicle details about treatments as well as other personal asides unrelated to health. Remember, they aren’t written by experts and shouldn’t be used for medical advice.

items: Julie’s Myeloma Moments, Musings and Living Life with a Bucket List

content_blocks.text: This website lists many blogs written by people with myeloma and links to recent posts in one place: https://www.myelomablogs.org

sections.heading: Online Communities
content: Many of the nonprofit organizations listed above have social media accounts on all the major platforms. Follow the links on the organization’s website to be sure get the official accounts.

content_blocks.text: Many of the nonprofit organizations listed above have social media accounts on all the major platforms. Follow the links on the organization’s website to be sure get the official accounts.

sections.heading: Facebook.
content: You can join multiple groups for people with multiple myeloma, or their loved ones. Most are private -- send a request and answer the questions to join. You can search the past discussions or ask your own questions.
This public Facebook page links to news and events related to the condition.
Reddit. You can read posts from multiple myeloma patients and caregivers in this dedicated forum. You don’t have to join to browse the conversation.
Hashtags. Search the hashtags #multiplemyeloma, #multiplemyelomaawareness or #myelomaawareness on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter.
There’s a huge range of information on social media, so be cautious. Make sure you’re following reputable sources and getting the facts.
bullets: Look for a symbol that says the account is verified.
Visit the account’s bio and website for more context and details.
Check for the original source of information.

meta_description: Get an overview of nonprofit organizations, blogs, and online communities with information about multiple myeloma.
